docs.snippet: KENNETH L. LAY and his second in command, Jeffrey K. Skilling, were the public faces of Enron, painting a rosy picture of strong profits and healthy businesses. But as the facts began to tumble out, in the fall of 2001, the company swiftly collaps...
docs.lead_paragraph: KENNETH L. LAY and his second in command, Jeffrey K. Skilling, were the public faces of Enron, painting a rosy picture of strong profits and healthy businesses. But as the facts began to tumble out, in the fall of 2001, the company swiftly collapsed, taking with it the fortunes and retirement savings of thousands of employees. Tomorrow is the first day of the trial of Mr. Lay, who as founder and chairman is accused of seven counts of fraud and conspiracy, and Mr. Skilling, his chief executive, who faces dozens of counts, including fraud, conspiracy and insider trading.
docs.abstract: Article on 10 major figures in Enron trial and where they are now; says Lou Lung Pai, who headed several Enron divisions, resigned from company before it filed for bankruptcy and has not been charged with wrongdoing; holds Pai denies knowledge of any illegal accounting and lives with new wife and daughter in SugarLand, Tex; photo (S)

headline.main: 10 Enron Players: Where They Landed After the Fall

docs.snippet: KENNETH L. LAY and his second in command, Jeffrey K. Skilling, were the public faces of Enron, painting a rosy picture of strong profits and healthy businesses. But as the facts began to tumble out, in the fall of 2001, the company swiftly collaps...
docs.lead_paragraph: KENNETH L. LAY and his second in command, Jeffrey K. Skilling, were the public faces of Enron, painting a rosy picture of strong profits and healthy businesses. But as the facts began to tumble out, in the fall of 2001, the company swiftly collapsed, taking with it the fortunes and retirement savings of thousands of employees. Tomorrow is the first day of the trial of Mr. Lay, who as founder and chairman is accused of seven counts of fraud and conspiracy, and Mr. Skilling, his chief executive, who faces dozens of counts, including fraud, conspiracy and insider trading.
docs.abstract: Article on 10 major figures in Enron trial and where they are now; says Kenneth Rice was indicted in 2003 on more than 40 charges and pleaded guilty in 2004 to one count of securities fraud; notes he agreed to cooperate with federal prosecutors; says Rice testified at 2005 trial against co-workers accused of fraud at broadband unit; notes jury failed to reach verdict and case is to be retried in September; holds Rice is defendant in several shareholder lawsuits; lives with wife and children in Bellaire, Tex; photo (M)

headline.main: 10 Enron Players: Where They Landed After the Fall

docs.snippet: Just two weeks before his trial is set to begin in federal court, Jeffrey K. Skilling is readying for battle with a fresh outlook....
docs.lead_paragraph: Unshaven and wearing faded jeans and light tan hiking boots, Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron, strides quickly through the makeshift Houston branch of O'Melveny & Myers, the law firm defending him in his coming criminal trial. Lawyers greet him pleasantly as he fixes a morning coffee with his lead lawyer, Daniel Petrocelli. Near a window, Mr. Skilling shows off his doorless office, which uses shelving units for walls. His nameplate sits on the desk. A fake Wheaties box with his likeness is on the back shelf.

headline.main: Ex-Enron Chief Helps Build His Defense, and an Office for His Lawyers

docs.snippet: Enron's chief accounting officer, Richard A. Causey, may testify against Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, but what will he say?...
docs.lead_paragraph: At a top-level Enron management meeting in September 2001, a red-faced Richard A. Causey, the chief accounting officer, pounded the table after hearing his colleagues label the company's accounting practices as ''aggressive.'' According to executives in the room, Mr. Causey fumed that he considered such criticism a personal affront, adding that he would stake his career on the propriety of Enron's accounting. Yesterday, more than four years later, Mr. Causey entered a Houston courtroom and pleaded guilty to a single count of securities fraud, admitting that the way Enron accounted for its financial performance presented a false portrait to investors for at least two years. [Page C1.]

headline.main: In Enron Case, a Guilty Plea but No Certainties

docs.snippet: HOUSTON, July 12 (Reuters) - Prosecutors in the trial of five former executives of the Enron Corporation's failed Internet business wrapped up their arguments on Tuesday, accusing the former executives of lying about the unit's health and hiding i...
docs.lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in the trial of five former executives of the Enron Corporation's failed Internet business wrapped up their arguments on Tuesday, accusing the former executives of lying about the unit's health and hiding its huge losses. ''Their goal? To pump up Enron's stock price and line their own pockets,'' an assistant United States attorney, Ben Campbell, told the jury in closing arguments.

headline.main: Prosecutors Give Closing Arguments in Trial of Ex-Enron Officers

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    ''Machine at Work,'' by Paul Krugman (column, July 13), looks at one company, Enron, and its ties to Tom DeLay, the House majority leader. After reading it, though, you might get the impression that America's corporations and Mr....
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Machine at Work,'' by Paul Krugman (column, July 13), looks at one company, Enron, and its ties to Tom DeLay, the House majority leader. After reading it, though, you might get the impression that America's corporations and Mr. DeLay are plotting to take over our political system.
docs.abstract: Salvatore J Bommarito letter comments on July 13 Paul Krugman Op-Ed column on ties between Rep Tom Delay and Enron; says he should not tar all corporations with same brush

docs.snippet: Q: As the whistle-blower at Enron, you must find it strange to continue living in Houston.     The only time it is awkward is when you run into the executives that are part of the guilty group. At least seven people have pleaded guilty, but they d...
docs.lead_paragraph: Q: As the whistle-blower at Enron, you must find it strange to continue living in Houston. The only time it is awkward is when you run into the executives that are part of the guilty group. At least seven people have pleaded guilty, but they don't go to prison until all their witnessing is done.
docs.abstract: Q&A interview with Sherron Watkins, former Enron vice president who blew whistle on company fraud; photo (M)

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 6-6-04: QUESTIONS FOR SHERRON WATKINS

docs.snippet: Even today, it is not entirely clear how much of a direct role Gov. John G. Rowland played in the disastrous $220 million deal with Enron.    But things are much clearer on what might be called Enron II, a proposal to develop a $124 million fuel-c...
docs.lead_paragraph: Even today, it is not entirely clear how much of a direct role Gov. John G. Rowland played in the disastrous $220 million deal with Enron. But things are much clearer on what might be called Enron II, a proposal to develop a $124 million fuel-cell farm, an alternative-energy project with the potential to produce energy without dangerous emissions.
docs.abstract: Documents show that Enron representatives promoting fuel-cell farm project met in former Connecticut Gov John Rowland's office before state's trash authority pledged in writing to pursue $220 deal with Enron that turned into disaster for state; Rowland initially denied meetings took place; other documents point to many contacts between Enron officials and Rowland as negotiations ensued; sticking point in deal came when Public Utility Control Dept balked at idea of paying for project with money raised from ratepayers primarily for conservation projects; trash authority then hired law firm in which Rowland's executive assistant Christine Corey's husband was partner, which is barred by state ethics rules (M)

headline.main: Before a Fuel-Cell Deal, Enron Lobbyists Met With Rowland

docs.snippet: Federal prosecutors scored a big win yesterday in the two-year-old Enron probe, when Andrew and Lea Fastow entered their guilty pleas in Houston. Mr. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron who helped mastermind the company's fraud, wi...
docs.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors scored a big win yesterday in the two-year-old Enron probe, when Andrew and Lea Fastow entered their guilty pleas in Houston. Mr. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron who helped mastermind the company's fraud, will now become a cooperating witness as prosecutors put other former Enron officials on trial. With his help, the government also has a better chance of indicting Jeffrey Skilling and Kenneth Lay, the energy-trading company's former top bosses. Leslie Caldwell, the lead prosecutor brought in after federal prosecutors in Houston recused themselves, deserves credit for painstakingly building a case against Mr. Fastow. Mr. Fastow was indicted on 98 counts of fraud more than a year ago, but in the end it appears to have been the indictment of his wife, who had also been an Enron employee, that forced him to succumb. Because they have young children, the married couple's primary concern was not to serve jail time at the same time.
docs.abstract: Editorial on big win for federal prosecutors in guilty pleas by Andrew Fastow, who masterminded Enron fraud, and his wife Lea

docs.snippet: The former top two executives of Enron as well as former directors, accountants and inside and outside lawyers are in ''a circle of responsibility for Enron's financial demise'' whether or not they are legally culpable, an examiner appointed by th...
docs.lead_paragraph: The former top two executives of Enron as well as former directors, accountants and inside and outside lawyers are in ''a circle of responsibility for Enron's financial demise'' whether or not they are legally culpable, an examiner appointed by the bankruptcy court has concluded. In his fourth and final report, made public Monday, Richard Neal Batson said enough evidence existed to prove that the former chairman of Enron, Kenneth L. Lay, and the former chief executive, Jeffrey K. Skilling, failed to adequately oversee Enron's use of financing methods to hide debt and inflate profits, which led to the company's collapse.
docs.abstract: Richard Neal Batson, bankruptcy court examiner looking at Enron case, concludes that Kenneth L Lay, former chairman, and Jeffrey Skilling, former chief executive, as well as former directors, accountants and inside and outside lawyers are in 'a circle of responsibility for Enron's financial demise' whether or not they are legally culpable (M)

headline.main: Bankruptcy Examiner Finds Enron's Top Leaders Neglectful
